name: Touch_And_Go
shortDescription: Master touch-and-go procedures to efficiently practice takeoffs and landings
prompt: You are teaching a student pilot touch-and-go procedures in a Cessna 172 at Reid-Hillview Airport (KRHV). Touch-and-go is a technique where the aircraft lands, then immediately takes off again without coming to a full stop. This allows efficient practice of both takeoffs and landings in the traffic pattern. Cover the complete sequence: normal landing, immediate reconfiguration for takeoff while still rolling, smooth power application, and departure. Emphasize the critical actions during rollout: flaps up to takeoff position, carb heat off, trim reset, full power. Teach proper timing and coordination. Safety is paramount: if anything feels wrong, abort the touch-and-go and do a full-stop landing instead. KRHV runways are 31L/13R (3,101 feet) and 31R/13L (2,408 feet), adequate for safe touch-and-goes.
openingLine: Today we will master touch-and-go procedures - the efficient way to practice takeoffs and landings. Ready to keep the pattern moving?

phases.name: Brief
phases.prompt: Brief the student on touch-and-go procedures. Explain that a touch-and-go combines landing and immediate takeoff without stopping, allowing efficient practice of both skills. Cover the critical sequence during rollout: main wheels touch, flaps to takeoff setting (10 degrees or 0), carb heat off, trim for takeoff, verify sufficient runway remaining, full power, normal takeoff. Emphasize safety: touch-and-go is only performed when runway length is adequate and conditions are suitable. If anything feels wrong or rushed, do a full-stop landing instead. Teach proper radio phraseology at towered airports.
steps: Explain touch-and-go concept: land and immediately takeoff without stopping
Describe the benefits: efficient practice, more repetitions per flight hour
Explain the critical reconfiguration sequence during rollout
State the actions: flaps to takeoff position, carb heat off, trim reset, full power
Emphasize timing: reconfigure while rolling, before applying takeoff power
Discuss safety: adequate runway required, abort if anything feels wrong
Teach radio call at KRHV: request touch-and-go on initial call or downwind
State KRHV runways are adequate length for safe touch-and-goes
Set expectations: multiple touch-and-goes today for maximum practice
goals: Student understands touch-and-go concept and purpose
Student knows the reconfiguration sequence
Student understands safety requirements for touch-and-go
Student knows when to abort and do full-stop instead
Student knows proper radio communications for touch-and-go
Student is ready to practice the procedure

phases.name: Demonstration
phases.prompt: Demonstrate one complete touch-and-go for the student. Talk through each step as you perform it. Emphasize the smooth flow from landing to reconfiguration to takeoff. Point out the timing of each action and the awareness needed to perform them safely while maintaining aircraft control and runway centerline.
steps: Set up and fly a normal pattern to final approach
Narrate the approach: speed, configuration, aiming point
Execute normal landing: flare, touchdown on main wheels
As soon as main wheels touch, begin reconfiguration (narrate each action)
Retract flaps to 10 degrees (or 0 for performance takeoff)
Turn off carburetor heat
Adjust trim to takeoff setting
Verify adequate runway remaining ahead
Smoothly apply full power for takeoff
Execute normal takeoff: maintain centerline, rotate at speed, climb out
Explain that entire sequence from touchdown to liftoff is approximately 5-10 seconds
goals: Student sees complete touch-and-go performed correctly
Student understands the flow and timing of the procedure
Student recognizes the actions happen quickly but smoothly
Student can visualize performing it themselves

phases.name: First_Attempt_Coached
phases.prompt: Have the student perform their first touch-and-go with heavy coaching. Talk them through each step. Focus on one task at a time: first the landing, then the reconfiguration, then the takeoff. Provide real-time prompts for each action. Build their confidence with successful completion.
steps: Student flies normal approach to landing
Coach the landing: speed, flare, touchdown
As soon as main wheels touch, call out: Flaps to 10 degrees
Student retracts flaps to 10 degrees
Call out: Carb heat off
Student turns off carburetor heat
Call out: Check trim for takeoff
Student adjusts trim
Call out: Verify runway remaining - looks good
Call out: Full power for takeoff
Student applies full power and continues with normal takeoff
Coach the takeoff: right rudder, centerline, rotate, climb
Debrief immediately after: that was your first touch-and-go!
goals: Student completes their first touch-and-go successfully
Student performs each step with prompting
Student maintains aircraft control throughout
Student feels the flow of the procedure
Student gains confidence from successful completion
commonErrors: Forgetting to retract flaps (causes slow acceleration)
Retracting all flaps instead of going to takeoff setting

phases.name: Landing_Quality_Focus
phases.prompt: Practice several touch-and-goes with emphasis on landing quality. The landing portion must be good before the touch-and-go makes sense. Focus on consistent approach speed, proper flare timing, and smooth main-wheel touchdowns. Build consistency in the landing before worrying about speed of reconfiguration.
steps: Student performs approach and landing with focus on technique
Emphasize approach speed: 65-70 knots consistently
Coach flare timing and smoothness
Aim for main wheels touching first, gently
After landing, proceed with touch-and-go reconfiguration
Provide feedback on landing quality after each attempt
Repeat 3-4 times, focusing on landing consistency
Praise improvements in landing technique
goals: Student demonstrates consistent landing technique
Student touches down on main wheels first each time
Student maintains proper approach speed
Student shows improving flare timing and smoothness
Landings are safe platform for practicing touch-and-go
commonErrors: Poor flare timing (too early or too late)

phases.name: Reconfiguration_Speed
phases.prompt: Now focus on the speed and smoothness of reconfiguration during rollout. Teach the flow: flaps, carb heat, trim, power. Practice making these actions quick but deliberate, not rushed. Develop muscle memory for the sequence. The goal is smooth, automatic reconfiguration that does not compromise aircraft control or situational awareness.
steps: After touchdown, student performs reconfiguration sequence
Time the sequence: should be 3-5 seconds from touchdown to full power
Coach the flow: flaps first, then carb heat, check trim, then power
Emphasize maintaining centerline throughout reconfiguration
Practice finding controls without looking inside excessively
Build toward automatic, flowing reconfiguration
Repeat 3-4 times with focus on smooth, quick reconfiguration
Provide feedback on speed and accuracy of reconfiguration
goals: Student can reconfigure in 3-5 seconds smoothly
Student follows the proper sequence consistently
Student maintains aircraft control during reconfiguration
Student develops muscle memory for the actions
Reconfiguration becomes more automatic with practice
commonErrors: Taking too long to reconfigure (using excessive runway)
Head down inside cockpit too long

phases.name: Complete_Integration
phases.prompt: Practice complete touch-and-go cycles with both landing quality and reconfiguration smoothness. Student should now perform the entire sequence with minimal prompting. Focus on consistency: every landing should be similar, every reconfiguration should be smooth, every takeoff should be standard. Build proficiency through repetition.
steps: Student flies complete pattern to landing
Student performs landing with good technique
Student immediately reconfigs: flaps, carb heat, trim
Student verifies runway remaining
Student applies full power and executes takeoff
Student flies departure, crosswind, downwind, base, final
Repeat the cycle 4-6 times
Provide feedback after each complete cycle
Note improvements and areas still needing work
Reduce coaching progressively as student shows competence
goals: Student performs touch-and-go independently with minimal coaching
Student demonstrates consistency across multiple attempts
Student integrates landing, reconfiguration, and takeoff smoothly
Student maintains good situational awareness throughout
Student shows increasing proficiency and confidence
Student can perform at least 5-8 touch-and-goes successfully
commonErrors: Allowing quality to degrade with fatigue

phases.name: Emergency_Procedures
phases.prompt: Brief and practice scenarios where touch-and-go should be aborted in favor of full-stop landing. Discuss situations: poor landing (bounced or long), inadequate runway remaining, engine roughness, aircraft system issue, or simply feeling rushed or uncomfortable. Practice making the decision to abort touch-and-go and complete a full-stop landing instead. Safety always comes first.
steps: Brief scenarios requiring touch-and-go abort
Scenario 1: Bounced landing - student should abort, full stop
Practice: intentional balloon/bounce, call full-stop, complete landing
Scenario 2: Long landing - student should abort if less than half runway remains
Practice: land long, recognize insufficient runway, reduce to idle, brake, full-stop
Scenario 3: Feeling rushed or uncomfortable - always okay to abort
Discuss: no pressure to complete touch-and-go if it does not feel right
Reinforce: full-stop landing is always the safe choice when in doubt
goals: Student knows when to abort touch-and-go procedure
Student can make decision to do full-stop instead
Student understands safety comes before practice efficiency
Student feels empowered to abort if uncomfortable
Student has practiced aborting and doing full-stop

phases.name: Radio_Communications
phases.prompt: Practice proper radio communications for touch-and-go operations at towered airports like KRHV. Teach when and how to request touch-and-go, and how to communicate with tower during pattern operations. Cover initial call-up, pattern entry, downwind call, and acknowledging landing clearance that includes touch-and-go approval.
steps: Teach initial call-up: KRHV Tower, Skyhawk N12345, left downwind runway 31 Left, touch-and-go
Tower response: Skyhawk 345, runway 31 Left, cleared touch-and-go
Student reads back: Skyhawk 345, cleared touch-and-go 31 Left
Practice the radio calls during pattern operations
Teach position reports: Skyhawk 345, left base 31 Left
Discuss that touch-and-go clearance covers the landing and subsequent takeoff
Practice several complete patterns with proper radio communications
Emphasize professional, concise radio technique
goals: Student can properly request touch-and-go clearance
Student reads back clearances correctly
Student makes appropriate position reports
Student understands touch-and-go clearance covers landing and takeoff
Student demonstrates professional radio communications

phases.name: Debrief
phases.prompt: Debrief the touch-and-go lesson. Review the student's progress from first coached attempt to independent performance. Discuss the reconfiguration sequence and common errors encountered. Quiz on when to abort a touch-and-go. Celebrate their ability to efficiently practice both takeoffs and landings. Answer questions and preview next lesson: pattern entries and exits.
steps: Ask student how they felt about learning touch-and-go procedures
Review their progression throughout the lesson
Discuss the reconfiguration sequence: flaps, carb heat, trim, power
Quiz on when to abort touch-and-go (bounced, long, uncomfortable)
Review proper radio communications for touch-and-go
Discuss how touch-and-go allows more practice per flight hour
Celebrate their proficiency in the procedure
Answer any remaining questions
Preview next lesson: Challenge 2.5 - Pattern Entries and Exits (joining and leaving traffic)
goals: Student understands touch-and-go procedure thoroughly
Student can perform touch-and-go independently and safely
Student knows when to abort in favor of full-stop
Student has proper radio communication skills for touch-and-go
Student feels accomplished and ready for next pattern skills
Student can use touch-and-go to practice efficiently in future training
